column1: Fokino (Russian: Фо́кино) is a closed town in Primorsky Krai
column3: located on the coast of the Peter the Great Gulf
column5: about 45 kilometers (28 mi) south of Vladivostok
column6: the administrative center of the krai. Population: 23
column8: 457 (2002 Census).It was previously known as Tikhookeansky (until 1980)

column1: The village of Promyslovka was founded on the current site of Fokino in 1891. Promyslovka was granted urban-type settlement status in 1958
column2: and the nearby naval village of Tikhookeansky followed suit in 1963. The settlements grew together
column4: and were granted town status on October 4
column6: due to its status as a base for the Russian Pacific Fleet
column8: and referred to officially under the code name Shkotovo-17. Since 1994
column9: Fokino has been the official name of the town.After the APEC-2012 Summit was held in Vladivostok
column10: Fokino will become the main naval base at the Russian Far East
column11: where the Russian Pacific Fleet will be attached.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column3: together with two urban-type settlements (Dunay and Putyatin)
column4: incorporated as Fokino Town Under Krai Jurisdiction—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column5: Fokino Town Under Krai Jurisdiction is incorporated as Fokino Urban Okrug.

column1: It is a closed town because the Russian Pacific Fleet is based there. Foreigners must have a special permit to visit the town. However
column2: the Islands of Putyatin and Askold
column3: which are a part of the territory administered by the town
column4: are open for visits by tourists. Up to two thousand tourists visit Putyatin every year. They are attracted by the unique flora and fauna in the waters surrounding this island and its underwater landscape. Approximately 2
column5: 400 people inhabit Putyatin Island. Their main occupation is catching and processing sea products

column1: There is no permanent population on Askold. It is rarely visited by tourists because of the absence of regular transport connections with the mainland
column2: and the status of the island which until 1995 had formed part of the Reserve where no economic activity was allowed. There are deposits of gold estimated at dozens of tonnes on Askold.
